description: Inherited from Middle English yong, yonge, from Old English ġeong, from Proto-West Germanic *jung, from Proto-Germanic *jungaz, from Proto-Indo-European *h₂yuh₁n̥ḱós, from *h₂yuh₁en- (“young”).

entries.meaning: In the early part of growth or life; born not long ago.
examples: Bliss was it in that dawn to be alive,But to be young was very heaven!

entries.meaning: At an early stage of existence or development; having recently come into existence.
examples: the age of space travel is still young;   a young business

entries.meaning: (Not) advanced in age; (far towards or) at a specified stage of existence or age.
examples: And thou, our Mother, twice two centuries young,
Bend with bright shafts of truth thy bow fresh-strung.

entries.meaning: Junior (of two related people with the same name).
examples: The young Mr. Chester must be in the wrong, and the old Mr. Chester must be in the right.
[…]  Miss Hessy is as pretty a girl as eye can see, in her young twenties and a bit of a fortune to boot.

entries.meaning: Youthful; having the look or qualities of a young person.
examples: My grandmother is a very active woman and is quite young for her age.

entries.meaning: Of or belonging to the early part of life.
examples: The cynical world soon shattered my young dreams.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Having little experience; inexperienced; unpracticed; ignorant; weak.
(often as if a plural noun) Offspring, especially the immature offspring of animals.
examples: There is a logic in this behavior: a mother will not come into breeding condition again unless her young is ready to be weaned or has died, so killing a baby may hasten  […]

verbs.description: young (third-person singular simple present youngs, present participle younging, simple past and past participle younged)

entries.meaning: (informal or demography) To become or seem to become younger.
(informal or demography) To cause to appear younger.
